questions.text: You, as a junior resident, are posted in a Pre-anesthesia clinic. You received a 30-year-old patient posted for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy for preoperative evaluation. The advantages of preoperative evaluation include all except:

options.label: A
options.text: Reduces the perioperative morbidity and mortality

options.label: C
options.text: Reduces the cancellation rate of surgeries

options.label: D
options.text: Improved acceptance of regional anesthesia by patients

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increases the overall cost Preop evaluation by anesthetists in the preoperative period reduces the cost by decreasing the cost of investigations by selectively choosing the investigation for each patient.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- There are studies to prove that if the patients are properly evaluated in the preoperative period, it can reduce perioperative morbidity and mortality. Option C- Proper evaluation and stabilization of medical condition can significantly reduce the chances of last-minute cancellations Option D- Good counseling by an anesthetist during preoperative assessment can increase the acceptance of regional anesthesia.

questions.text: The most important factor during preoperative evaluation determining the perioperative morbidity and mortality is:

options.label: A
options.text: History of 20 pack years of smoking

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic equivalents for the task (MET) less than 2

questions.correct_answer: C. Metabolic equivalents for the task (MET) less than 2
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metabolic equivalents for the task (MET) less than 2 Poor effort tolerance is the most important factor determining perioperative morbidity and mortality

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and D- All of the factors mentioned above like chronic smoking, and pre existing medical diseases like hypertension, MI, and diabetes increases the perioperative morbidity and mortality, however, poor effort tolerance is the most important factor determining morbidity as well as mortality.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female is posted for laparoscopic hysterectomy under GA. In the comments on the preoperative evaluation form, the anesthetist mentioned “Anticipate difficult intubation due to less thyromental distance. The distance would have been less than:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

6.5 cm Thyromental distance is a very important predictor of difficult intubation. It is the distance between the thyroid notch and the mentum with the neck in full extension. Normal is > 6.5 cm

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- 0-6.5 predicts difficult intubation while distance < 6.0 makes intubation almost impossible Options C & D- Intubation should not be difficult if the thyromental distance is > 6.5 cm

questions.text: Mallampati score is used in:

options.label: B
options.text: Flexion and extension of the neck during intubation

options.label: D
options.text: To assess difficulty in intubation in the oral cavity

questions.correct_answer: D. To assess difficulty in intubation in the oral cavity
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To assess difficulty in intubation in the oral cavity Mallampati classification is used for assessing mouth opening. Depending on the structures seen, the classification is: Class 1: Faucial pillars, soft palate, and uvula. Class 2: Faucial pillars and soft palate seen but not uvula. Class 3: Only soft palate seen. Class 4: Only hard palate visible

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- there is nothing thoracoabdominal curvature which is assessed in anesthesia Option B & C- Movement of the neck in all planes i.e., flexion, extension, and rotation is assessed as a part of airway assessment but does not constitute Mallampati classification.

Extraedge:

Class 4 was not originally described by Mallampati it was described by Sampson and Young. Some authors also describe Mallampati 0, if the posterior wall of the pharynx/epiglottis can be visualized.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is posted for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. On preoperative evaluation, the following image of the oral cavity is seen. True about the following image:

options.label: A
options.text: It is a modified Mallampati classification

options.label: B
options.text: Original Mallampati classification is now called modified Mallampati grading

options.label: C
options.text: Grading 3 means oral intubation is impossible

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a modified Mallampati classification
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a modified Mallampati classification It is a modified Mallampati classification which was described by Sampson and Young.

Highyeild:

Class 1- Faucial pillars, fauces, Uvula, soft palate Class II- Fauces, Uvula (major part), soft palate Class III- Uvula (base), soft palate Class 1V- Soft palate not visible (Only hard palate)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- It is very evident that the modified Mallampati is different from Mallampati in a manner that the 4th structure i.e., Fauces (entry to oropharynx) has been added. Option D- Grade 3 means oral intubation is difficult but not impossible

Extraedge:

Grade 1 and 2 means oral intubation is easy Grade 3 means oral intubation is difficult but not impossible Grade 4 means oral intubation is impossible so either the patient has to be intubated through the nasal route or tracheostomy.

questions.text: A 60-year male is posted for herniorrhaphy. He is a known case of Diabetes, HT and Ischemic heart disease, and dilated cardiomyopathy. He has an ejection fraction of only 20%, has dyspnea at rest, and is not able to do even routine activity. His ASA status will be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IV American Society of Anesthesiologists has classified patients into six categories based on their medical condition to assess the risk of mortality and morbidity during anesthesia

Highyeild:

ASA Grading is as follows: Normal healthy patient. The patients having mild systemic disease that does not limit functional activity. Severe systemic disease that limits functional activity but not incapacitating. An incapacitating disease that is a constant threat to life. Moribund patient. Brain-dead

questions.text: A 60-year-old hypertensive patient on angiotensin II receptor antagonist is posted for hernia repair surgery. The hypertensive drug should be (easy):

options.label: A
options.text: Omit on the day of operation

options.label: D
options.text: Administered in increased dosage on the day of operation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Discontinued 24 hours preoperatively All antihypertensive should be continued up to the day of surgery except angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) which should be stopped 24 hours before surgery.

Highyeild:

Continuing angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) not only increase the risk of intraoperative hypotension but also increase the risks of postoperative myocardial injury. However, they should be restarted postoperatively once patients are hemodynamically stable because failure to restart early can have detrimental effects.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Omitting on the day of surgery was the previous recommendation Option C- Stopping 1 week before can lead to uncontrolled BP Option D- Even continuing can lead to exaggerated hypotension so increasing the dosing can cause profound hypotension in the intraoperative period

questions.text: A 35-year female patient on high dose estrogen-containing oral contraceptive is posted for cholecystectomy:

options.label: A
options.text: It should be stopped 4 weeks before

options.label: C
options.text: To be continued while omitting the morning dose

options.label: D
options.text: To be continued and morning dose should be taken

questions.correct_answer: A. It should be stopped 4 weeks before
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It should be stopped 4 weeks before Estrogen increases the chances of postoperative deep vein thrombosis, so pills containing a standard dose of estrogen should be stopped 4 weeks before surgery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B - Dose reduction is not advocated Option C - Omitting in the morning is not sufficient Option D- High-dose estrogen we cannot continue pills containing only progesterone or low-dose estrogen need not be stopped.

Extraedge:

A pill containing only progesterone or low-dose estrogen does not increase the risk of thromboembolism therefore needs not be stopped.

questions.text: A patient aged 50 years of NIDDM with controlled diabetes is posted for joint replacement, he should be:

options.label: C
options.text: Oral hypoglycemics are to be continued omitting the morning dose

options.label: D
options.text: Oral hypoglycemics are to be continued with a morning dose to be taken

questions.correct_answer: C. Oral hypoglycemics are to be continued omitting the morning dose
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral hypoglycemics are to be continued omitting the morning dose Oral hypoglycemic should be continued, omitting the morning dose.

Highyeild:

Previously oral hypoglycemics were omitted on the day of surgery for only minor surgeries and for major surgeries patients used to be switched to insulin at least 24-48 hours before surgery. However, now a day all patients irrespective of the surgery are continued on oral hypoglycemics, and the morning dose is omitted.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Switching to short-acting insulin is required if the patient sugar is not controlled Option B- It is difficult to control sugar on long-acting acting insulin. In fact, patients on long-acting insulin are also switched to short-acting Option D- Continuing oral hypoglycemics on the day of surgery increases the chances of hypoglycemia.

Extraedge:

Sulfonylurea and metformin have longer half-lives so they need to be stopped 24-48 hours before surgery.

questions.text: A 60-year patient with chronic atrial fibrillation is posted for cataract surgery under the block. In history, it was revealed that the patient is taking warfarin. INR was found to be 2.8. Regarding warfarin, it should be stopped how many days before surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: To be continued as cataract is a minor surgery

questions.explanation:
Solution:

5 days Warfarin (Coumadin) should be stopped 5 days prior to surgery

Highyeild:

If stopping of Warfarin is not possible then switch over to heparin which is stopped 12-24 hours prior to surgery. In case of urgency, oral anticoagulants can be reversed with vitamin K (if it is not possible to wait for 6-12 hours) In case of emergency, patients can be taken up for surgery after transfusing fresh frozen plasma.

questions.text: Minimum INR before any elective surgery should be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Less than 1.5 Warfarin should be stopped 5 days prior to surgery However, before taking the patient for surgery it is mandatory to check INR before surgery. INR must be < 1.5 to consider the patient for surgery

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B- INR > 1.5 not only increases the risk of surgical bleeding but also becomes a contraindication of regional anesthesia unnecessarily subjecting the patients to the risks of general anesthesia. Option D- A normal INR may increase the chances of thrombosis in these vulnerable patients who are on anticoagulants. Therefore, the target is not to achieve normal INR. INR < 1.5 does not increase the risk of bleeding and decreases the risk of thrombosis therefore the target is to keep INR below 1.5.

questions.text: An old patient with Parkinsonism is posted for TURP. The patient is on Levodopa. Regarding the timing to stop Levodopa before surgery:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To be continued The recent recommendation is to continue the levodopa otherwise there is the possibility of muscle rigidity in the perioperative period.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A and B- Previous recommendation was to stop levodopa 12-24 hours before surgery Option C- Stopping 12 hours was never the recommendation

questions.text: A 47-year patient with a history of MI 1 year back is posted for herniorrhaphy. The MI was managed conservatively after keeping the patient in CCU for 2 days. On drug history, it was found that currently, the patient is on aspirin. Aspirin should be stopped:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

72 hours before surgery As per new guidelines, Aspirin should be stopped 73 hours prior to surgery

Highyeild:

It was found in studies that continuing aspirin does not decrease the incidence of perioperative MI, but rather increases the risk of bleeding therefore as per new guidelines aspirin should be stopped 72 hours before surgery except in 3 situations: Patients with coronary stents Recent MI within 2 months Recent stroke within 9 months

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Until very recently Aspirin used to be continued Options B & C- Over the last one and half decades stopping aspirin for 24, 48 hours, or even 5 days has been practiced.

Extraedge:

The second commonly used antiplatelet, Clopidogrel should be stopped 5 days before surgery

questions.text: A 66-year female is posted for Whipple surgery for pancreatic malignancy. During the preoperative evaluation, it was found that the patient is on a prophylactic dose of low molecular-weight heparin. LMWH should be stopped:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

12 hours before surgery A prophylactic dose of LMWH should be stopped 12 hours before surgery

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Unfractionated heparin need to be stopped 6 hours prior to surgery. Option C- If the patient is on a therapeutic dose, then it should be stopped 24 hours before surgery Option D- There is no need to stop 48 hours before surgery, 24 hours are enough even for a therapeutic dose.

questions.text: What is the most acute effect of smoking cessation?

options.label: A
options.text: Shift of oxyhemoglobin curve to the right

questions.correct_answer: A. Shift of oxyhemoglobin curve to the right
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Shift of oxyhemoglobin curve to the right Smoking should preferably be stopped 8 weeks before surgery because complete recovery of ciliary activity takes place in 6-8 weeks. Stopping smoking even 12 hours before is beneficial as it decreases nicotine (which improves cardiac function) and carbon monoxide levels (which decreases carboxyhemoglobin levels thus shifting the oxygen dissociation curve to the right thereby improving O2 delivery to tissues).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Complete ciliary recovery takes 8 weeks. Even 50% of ciliary recovery takes 3 weeks Option C- Stopping smoking 1-2 weeks before will reduce sputum volume. Option D- patient develops pneumonia because of decreased ciliary activity, therefore, smoking should be stopped 8 weeks prior to decrease the incidence of pneumonia

questions.text: Which one of the following is true of adrenal suppression due to steroid therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not associated with atrophy of the adrenal glands

options.label: B
options.text: It does not occur in patients receiving inhaled steroids

options.label: C
options.text: It should be expected in anyone receiving > 5 mg, of prednisolone daily

options.label: D
options.text: Following cessation, the stress response normalizes after 8 weeks

questions.correct_answer: D. Following cessation, the stress response normalizes after 8 weeks
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Following cessation, the stress response normalizes after 8 weeks In any patient who has taken steroids from any route (oral, inhalational, parenteral) for more than 3 weeks in doses of 5 mg/day or more of prednisolone (or its equivalent) there occurs significant suppression of pituitary adrenal axis, the recovery of which takes place in 1 year.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Chronic use of steroids can cause suppression or even atrophy of adrenals Option B- Studies have shown that taking a steroid for more than 3 weeks by any route including topical and inhalational leads to significant blood levels which can suppress the adrenals Option C- The suppression of adrenal is only seen if the doses are >5 mg/day or more of prednisolone (or its equivalent)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about calcium channel blockers in a patient undergoing surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Should be withdrawn prior to surgery since it decreases the tone of LES

options.label: B
options.text: Need to be decreased as they augment hypotension and muscle relaxation

options.label: C
options.text: Normal doses should be given as they prevent MI and angina

options.label: D
options.text: Should be given to patients with malignant hyperthermia

questions.correct_answer: C. Normal doses should be given as they prevent MI and angina
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Normal doses should be given as they prevent MI and angina The calcium channel blockers should be continued as such and even the morning dose must be taken with a sip of water otherwise exacerbation of angina may occur.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- withdrawal of calcium channel blockers can precipitate MI Option B- The doses should remain the same Option D- there is no role of calcium channel blockers in the treatment of malignant hyperthermia. The drug of choice for the treatment of malignant hyperthermia is dantrolene sodium

questions.text: In general, herbal medicines should be stopped how many days before surgery?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

7 days Although some herbal medications have a half-life as short as 24 hours, general recommendations by ASA advisory suggest that herbal medicines should be stopped 1 week prior to the surgery.

questions.text: Viagra or a similar drug should be stopped how many days before surgery?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

24 hours before Viagra or similar drugs cause sympathetic stimulation increasing the level of catecholamines. Further release in catecholamines due to the stress of surgery and anesthesia can precipitate life-threatening arrhythmias or hypertension in such patients. Therefore, these drugs should be stopped 24 hours before surgery

questions.text: Minimum ‘Starvation time’ required in GA prior to surgery:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

6 hours The patient should be kept nil orally for 6 hours for solid food

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Breast milk can be given up to 4 hours Option C- Clear liquid can be given up to 2 hours Option D- If the patient has taken fatty and/or non-vegetarian meals, then surgery must be delayed for 8 hours

Extraedge:

Clear fluid includes water, plain juices without pulp, tea, and coffee without milk. Tea or coffee with milk is classified as unclear fluids and fasting of 6 hours is required.

questions.text: A 60-year-old ASA 1 patient is posted for herniorrhaphy. All of the following investigations should be done preoperatively except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Routine preoperative investigations for asymptomatic patients are not recommended.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Complete blood count is recommended if there is an indication like the patient is clinically appearing pale, very high blood loss is expected in surgery, etc., not routinely in every patient as per recent guidelines Option B- Contrary to previous guidelines for doing ECG in all males above 40 and females above 50, nowadays ECG is not recommended routinely for asymptomatic patients. Option C- Renal function is recommended if the patient is a known case of renal diseases, chronic hypertension or chronic diabetes, etc.

questions.text: A 38-year controlled hypertensive male is posted for hernia repair surgery. He underwent routine testing as a part of his routine medical checkup at his office 1 month before where all test reports were normal. The anesthetist would like to repeat:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above There is no need to repeat any investigations done within 2 months if there is no change in the medical status of the patient

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and C- CBC, RFT, or ECG would been have needed if there had been some medical event in last 1 month in this patient

questions.text: Preanesthetic medication is used for all of the following, except:

options.label: D
options.text: Reduce the dose of inducing agents

questions.correct_answer: D. Reduce the dose of inducing agents
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reduce the dose of inducing agents Preanesthetic medication is not given to reduce the dose of inducing agents

Highyeild:

The aims of premedication are: To induce good sleep. To produce hemodynamic To provide amnesia and analgesia. To prevent nausea and vomiting in the postoperative To allay anxiety. To decrease tracheobronchial and oral secretions. To decrease chances of aspiration. Hemodynamic To prevent undesirable reflexes. To control infections.

Extraedge:

Among the goals mentioned above, premedication is most commonly utilized for relieving anxiety.

questions.text: Antiemetic prophylaxis should be given to all, except:

options.label: C
options.text: Patient being operated on for middle ear surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Patients with a frequent history of nausea and vomiting in the preoperative period

questions.explanation:
Solution:

To all patients routinely Present-day premedication guidelines do not advocate the use of antiemetics routinely for all patients. The use is reserved to patients who are very vulnerable for nausea and vomiting.

Highyeild:

Contrary to the previous practice of pre-medicating all patients with anxiolytics, antiemetic prophylaxis, drugs to decrease the chances of aspiration, or antisecretory drugs, the current recommendation does not advise routine premedication. Premedication should be given only if there is a clear indication.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Pregnancy patients are very vulnerable to develop post-operative nausea and vomiting. Option C- The incidence of nausea and vomiting after middle ear surgery can be as high as 30-40% Option D- It has been seen in studies that patients with a history of frequent vomiting have a higher incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting

questions.text: A 20 years boy is posted for removal of mass from the tongue. The preferred anticholinergic would be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glycopyrrolate Anticholinergics are not used as a routine practice. They are used only when required like for oral surgeries to facilitate dry mouth for surgery. Among anticholinergics, glycopyrrolate is preferred because its antisecretory property is better than atropine and it does not cross the blood-brain barrier so devoid of central side effects.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Atropine can cause severe tachycardia and central anticholinergic syndrome Option C- Scopolamine can cross the blood-brain barrier to cause central side effects. Moreover, it can produce can sedation

questions.text: Which of the following statement is/are true? Normal breath holding time is 25 seconds Mallampati grade II means oral intubation is impossible ASA grading is related to the outcome of anesthesia Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, and 3 are correct Breath-holding time is one of the most basic tests which can be performed to have an idea of pulmonary functions. In this test the patient is asked to take a full breath to his/her maximum vital capacity and then hold for the maximum time he or she can. If the patient is able to hold breath for > 25 seconds, it indicates that the patient has got good pulmonary reserve. In Mallampati grade II intubation should be easy ASA grading in a directly related outcome. The chances of mortality in ASA I patients is as low as 1 in 1,85,000 which can increase to 10-20% in ASA IV patient

questions.text: Which of the following statement is /are true? All hypertensives have to be continued before surgery All patients must be premedicated with Metoclopramide and ranitidine Lithium should be stopped 24 hours before surgery Select the correct answer from the below code:

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above is correct

questions.correct_answer: D. None of the above is correct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above is correct All antihypertensive drugs are continued except ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin receptors antagonists which are stopped a day before surgery. Routine premedication is not advisable. Metoclopramide and Ranitidine will be given only to patients who are at high risk of aspiration. Contrary to the previous recommendation of stopping Lithium 24-48 hours before surgery, the current recommendation is to continue lithium.

questions.text: Assertion- Herbal medication can be continued up to surgery Reason- As herbal medicines do not have side effects.

options.label: A
options.text: Both assertion and reasons are correct

options.label: B
options.text: Both assertion and reasons are incorrect

options.label: C
options.text: Both assertion and reasons are correct and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion

options.label: D
options.text: Both assertion and reasons are correct but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion

questions.correct_answer: B. Both assertion and reasons are incorrect
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both assertion and reasons are incorrect Different Herbal medications have different side effects. Therefore, as advised by ASA advisory, herbal medicines should be stopped 1 week prior to the surgery.

questions.text: Match the following: Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1- b, 2-a, 3-c Diuretics should be omitted on the day of surgery if not taken as antihypertensives. If taken as antihypertensives then they should be continued. Neostigmine and pyridostigmine are 2 edge swords. Stopping them can create myasthenia crises. while if we continue them, they can antagonize the effect of muscle relaxants. Therefore, the mid path is to continue but in minimal possible doses. Disulfiram should be discontinued 10 days before surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is /are true or false? NSAID should be continued before surgery Antibiotics should be given 30-60 minutes before the skin incision Antitubercular drugs can be continued only if LFT is normal Select the correct answer from the below code:

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above is correct

questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, and 3 are correct As per the new recommendation, NSAIDS should be stopped 48 hours prior to surgery As the maximum chances of contamination occur through the skin, therefore peak level of antibiotic should be at the time of skin incision. That's why antibiotics should be given 30-60 minutes before skin incision. Antitubercular drugs can be continued if the patient's LFT is normal.
